title: Your Mouth Learns Lojban
goal: Pronounce all Lojban vowels, diphthongs, and your first 3 gismu confidently.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

No prior material to review — this is Day 1. Instead, try saying these sounds aloud:

a  e  i  o  u

Say each one twice, slowly. These are your building blocks.

New Material (5-7 min)

Lojban Sounds

mi prami do — I love you.

Before you learn what that means (tomorrow), say it aloud. Notice: every letter sounds exactly like it looks. Lojban has no silent letters, no surprises.

The 6 Vowels

Letter Sounds like Example word
a father pr**a**mi
e bet m**e**lbi
i machine c**i**tka
o boat (no gismu this week starts with o)
u flute cu
y comma (schwa) only in compound words — ignore for now

Say each vowel five times. Keep them pure — no glide at the end. English speakers tend to turn "o" into "oh-oo" and "e" into "eh-ee." Don't. Hold the sound steady.

The 4 Common Diphthongs

A diphthong is two vowels gliding together in one syllable.

Diphthong Sounds like Example
ai buy prami ends near this
ei weigh
oi boy
au cow

Say each diphthong three times. These are the only diphthongs you'll use often.

Stress Rule

Lojban stress is simple: always on the second-to-last syllable (penultimate).

Word Syllables Stress
prami pra-mi wait — two syllables, stress the first: PRA-mi
klama KLA-ma
tavla TAV-la
citka CIT-ka

For two-syllable words, stress the first. For three-syllable words, stress the second. The rule is always the same: count from the end, land on the second-to-last.

Key Point

Every Lojban letter has exactly one sound. No exceptions, no silent letters. If you can read it, you can say it.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Pronunciation Drill

Say each word aloud. Focus on hitting the stressed syllable.

  1. prami — (PRA-mi)
  2. klama — (KLA-ma)
  3. tavla — (TAV-la)
  4. citka — (CIT-ka) — note: "c" is pronounced like English "sh"
  5. pinxe — (PIN-she) — note: "x" is pronounced like "kh" in Scottish "loch"
  6. cadzu — (CAD-zu) — remember: "c" = "sh"
  7. ciska — (CIS-ka)
  8. tcidu — (TCI-du) — "tc" = "tch" as in "match"
  9. sipna — (SIP-na)
  10. melbi — (MEL-bi)
  11. xamgu — (XAM-gu) — "x" = "kh"
  12. xlali — (XLA-li)

Go through the list twice. On the second pass, try to say each word without looking at the pronunciation hint.

Exercise 2: Vowel Identification

Which vowel sounds do you hear in each word? Say the word, then name the vowels.

  1. prami → ___, ___ (answer: a, i)
  2. klama → ___, ___ (answer: a, a)
  3. melbi → ___, ___ (answer: e, i)
  4. sipna → ___, ___ (answer: i, a)
  5. xamgu → ___, ___ (answer: a, u)

items.text: `pinxe` — (**PIN**-she) — note: "x" is pronounced like "kh" in Scottish "loch"

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

No grammar yet — just sounds. But you can already "speak" Lojban.

Say aloud:

  1. Say all 12 gismu in order, as fast as you can while keeping pronunciation clean.
  2. Say "prami, klama, tavla" three times, getting faster each time.
  3. Say this sentence (don't worry about the meaning yet): mi tavla do

Answer key:

  1. prami, klama, tavla, citka, pinxe, cadzu, ciska, tcidu, sipna, melbi, xamgu, xlali
  2. (speed drill — no answer needed)
  3. mi tavla do — you'll learn what this means tomorrow

sections.content:
Today's Vocab

These are all gismu — root words, always exactly 5 letters in the pattern CVCCV or CCVCV.

Lojban Place Structure English
prami x1 loves x2 love
klama x1 goes to x2 from x3 via x4 by x5 go
tavla x1 talks to x2 about x3 in language x4 talk

You're only responsible for these 3 today. Just know the word and roughly what it means. The full place structures come later.

items.place: x1 goes to x2 from x3 via x4 by x5
x1 talks to x2 about x3 in language x4

sections.content:
Consonant Quick Reference

Some consonants differ from English:

Letter Sound English equivalent
c "sh" ship
j "zh" measure
x "kh" Scottish loch
' "h" aha (between vowels)
. pause a glottal stop — a tiny silence

All other consonants (b, d, f, g, k, l, m, n, p, r, s, t, v, z) sound like English.

Summary

You learned Lojban's 6 vowels, 4 diphthongs, the stress rule (penultimate syllable), and a few tricky consonants (c = sh, j = zh, x = kh). You said your first 3 gismu aloud.

Tomorrow preview: You'll learn what mi, do, and cu mean, and build your first real Lojban sentences.
